##  Abstract:

##  Abstract:
IEEE Standard 1471 identifies sound practices to establish a framework and vocabulary for software architecture concepts.In 2000, the Computer Society approved IEEE Standard 1471, which documents a consensus on good architectural description practices. Five core concepts and relationships provide the foundation for the approved IEEE 1471 version: every system has an architecture, but an architecture is not a system; an architecture and an architecture description are not the same thing; architecture standards, descriptions, and development processes can differ and be developed separately; architecture descriptions are inherently multiviewed; and separating the concept of an object's view from its specification is an effective way to write architecture description standards. IEEE 1471 focuses on both software intensive systems and more general systems, such as information systems, embedded systems, systems-of-systems, product lines, and product families in which software plays a substantial role in development, operation, or evolution.
**Published in:**[Computer](https://ieeexplore.ieee.org/xpl/RecentIssue.jsp?punumber=2) ( Volume: 34, [Issue: 4](https://ieeexplore.ieee.org/xpl/tocresult.jsp?isnumber=19820&punumber=2), April 2001) 
**Page(s):** 107 - 109
**Date of Publication:** 30 April 2001 [](http://ieeexplore.ieee.org/Xplorehelp/Help_Pubdates.html)
**DOI:**[10.1109/2.917550](https://doi.org/10.1109/2.917550)
Publisher: IEEE
![](https://ieeexplore.ieee.org/assets/img/document/toc-icon.png) Contents 
* * *
###  What is an Architecture?
Although defining architecture in the context of computing might seem like a simple task, it became one of the most contentious issues in developing the standard. This is not surprising considering that, despite approximately 5,000 years of practice, the civil architecture community has had little more success in precisely defining a building's architecture. The difficulty with this subject, which was the last issue resolved in the balloting process, is that it required elaborating on the concept that an architecture is a very complex property of a system rather than a thing itself.

			<meta property="twitter:description" content="IEEE Standard 1471 identifies sound practices to establish a framework and vocabulary for software architecture concepts.In 2000, the Computer Society approved IEEE Standard 1471, which documents a consensus on good architectural description practices. Five core concepts and relationships provide the foundation for the approved IEEE 1471 version: every system has an architecture, but an architecture is not a system; an architecture and an architecture description are not the same thing; architecture standards, descriptions, and development processes can differ and be developed separately; architecture descriptions are inherently multiviewed; and separating the concept of an object's view from its specification is an effective way to write architecture description standards. IEEE 1471 focuses on both software intensive systems and more general systems, such as information systems, embedded systems, systems-of-systems, product lines, and product families in which software plays a substantial role in development, operation, or evolution.">
			<meta property="og:description" content="IEEE Standard 1471 identifies sound practices to establish a framework and vocabulary for software architecture concepts.In 2000, the Computer Society approved IEEE Standard 1471, which documents a consensus on good architectural description practices. Five core concepts and relationships provide the foundation for the approved IEEE 1471 version: every system has an architecture, but an architecture is not a system; an architecture and an architecture description are not the same thing; architecture standards, descriptions, and development processes can differ and be developed separately; architecture descriptions are inherently multiviewed; and separating the concept of an object's view from its specification is an effective way to write architecture description standards. IEEE 1471 focuses on both software intensive systems and more general systems, such as information systems, embedded systems, systems-of-systems, product lines, and product families in which software plays a substantial role in development, operation, or evolution.">

class="col-12"><div _ngcontent-ng-c63653188="" class="u-mb-1"><h2 _ngcontent-ng-c63653188=""> Abstract:</h2><div _ngcontent-ng-c63653188="" xplmathjax="">IEEE Standard 1471 identifies sound practices to establish a framework and vocabulary for software architecture concepts.In 2000, the Computer Society approved IEEE Standard 1471, which documents a consensus on good architectural description practices. Five core concepts and relationships provide the foundation for the approved IEEE 1471 version: every system has an architecture, but an architecture is not a system; an architecture and an architecture description are not the same thing; architecture standards, descriptions, and development processes can differ and be developed separately; architecture descriptions are inherently multiviewed; and separating the concept of an object's view from its specification is an effective way to write architecture description standards. IEEE 1471 focuses on both software intensive systems and more general systems, such as information systems, embedded systems, systems-of-systems, product lines, and product families in which software plays a substantial role in development, operation, or evolution.</div></div><!----><!----><!----></div><!----></div><!----><!----><!----><!----><div _ngcontent-ng-c63653188="" This is not surprising considering that, despite approximately 5,000 years of practice, the civil architecture community has had little more success in precisely defining a building's architecture. The difficulty with this subject, which was the last issue resolved in the balloting process, is that it required elaborating on the concept that an architecture is a very complex property of a system rather than a thing itself.</p></div></div><!----><xpl-reference-pop-up _ngcontent-ng-c3157741314="" parentid="full-text-section" _nghost-ng-c2399047529=""><!----></xpl-reference-pop-up><div 			<meta property="twitter:title" content="Software architecture: introducing IEEE Standard 1471">
			<meta property="og:title" content="Software architecture: introducing IEEE Standard 1471">
		
		
			<meta property="twitter:description" content="IEEE Standard 1471 identifies sound practices to establish a framework and vocabulary for software architecture concepts.In 2000, the Computer Society approved IEEE Standard 1471, which documents a consensus on good architectural description practices. Five core concepts and relationships provide the foundation for the approved IEEE 1471 version: every system has an architecture, but an architecture is not a system; an architecture and an architecture description are not the same thing; architecture standards, descriptions, and development processes can differ and be developed separately; architecture descriptions are inherently multiviewed; and separating the concept of an object's view from its specification is an effective way to write architecture description standards. IEEE 1471 focuses on both software intensive systems and more general systems, such as information systems, embedded systems, systems-of-systems, product lines, and product families in which software plays a substantial role in development, operation, or evolution.">
			<meta property="og:description" content="IEEE Standard 1471 identifies sound practices to establish a framework and vocabulary for software architecture concepts.In 2000, the Computer Society approved IEEE Standard 1471, which documents a consensus on good architectural description practices. Five core concepts and relationships provide the foundation for the approved IEEE 1471 version: every system has an architecture, but an architecture is not a system; an architecture and an architecture description are not the same thing; architecture standards, descriptions, and development processes can differ and be developed separately; architecture descriptions are inherently multiviewed; and separating the concept of an object's view from its specification is an effective way to write architecture description standards. IEEE 1471 focuses on both software intensive systems and more general systems, such as information systems, embedded systems, systems-of-systems, product lines, and product families in which software plays a substantial role in development, operation, or evolution.">

class="col-12"><div _ngcontent-ng-c63653188="" class="u-mb-1"><h2 _ngcontent-ng-c63653188=""> Abstract:</h2><div _ngcontent-ng-c63653188="" xplmathjax="">IEEE Standard 1471 identifies sound practices to establish a framework and vocabulary for software architecture concepts.In 2000, the Computer Society approved IEEE Standard 1471, which documents a consensus on good architectural description practices. Five core concepts and relationships provide the foundation for the approved IEEE 1471 version: every system has an architecture, but an architecture is not a system; an architecture and an architecture description are not the same thing; architecture standards, descriptions, and development processes can differ and be developed separately; architecture descriptions are inherently multiviewed; and separating the concept of an object's view from its specification is an effective way to write architecture description standards. IEEE 1471 focuses on both software intensive systems and more general systems, such as information systems, embedded systems, systems-of-systems, product lines, and product families in which software plays a substantial role in development, operation, or evolution.</div></div><!----><!----><!----></div><!----></div><!----><!----><!----><!----><div _ngcontent-ng-c63653188="" This is not surprising considering that, despite approximately 5,000 years of practice, the civil architecture community has had little more success in precisely defining a building's architecture. The difficulty with this subject, which was the last issue resolved in the balloting process, is that it required elaborating on the concept that an architecture is a very complex property of a system rather than a thing itself.</p></div></div><!----><xpl-reference-pop-up _ngcontent-ng-c3157741314="" parentid="full-text-section" _nghost-ng-c2399047529=""><!----></xpl-reference-pop-up><div What is an Architecture?

Although defining architecture in the context of computing might seem like a simple task, it became one of the most contentious issues in developing the standard. This is not surprising considering that, despite approximately 5,000 years of practice, the civil architecture community has had little more success in precisely defining a building's architecture. The difficulty with this subject, which was the last issue resolved in the balloting process, is that it required elaborating on the concep...

Abstract:

Abstract:

IEEE Standard 1471 identifies sound practices to establish a framework and vocabulary for software architecture concepts.In 2000, the Computer Society approved IEEE Standard 1471, which documents a consensus on good architectural description practices. Five core concepts and relationships provide the foundation for the approved IEEE 1471 version: every system has an architecture, but an architecture is not a system; an architecture and an architecture description are not the same thing; architecture standards, descriptions, and development processes can differ and be developed separately; architecture descriptions are inherently multiviewed; and separating the concept of an object's view from its specification is an effective way to write architecture description standards. IEEE 1471 focuses on both software intensive systems and more general systems, such as information systems, embedded systems, systems-of-systems, product lines, and product families in which software plays a substantial role in development, operation, or evolution.
Published in: Computer ( Volume: 34, Issue: 4, April 2001)
Page(s): 107 - 109
Date of Publication: 30 April 2001
DOI: 10.1109/2.917550
Contents

What is an Architecture?

Although defining architecture in the context of computing might seem like a simple task, it became one of the most contentious issues in developing the standard. This is not surprising considering that, despite approximately 5,000 years of practice, the civil architecture community has had little more success in precisely defining a building's architecture. The difficulty with this subject, which was the last issue resolved in the balloting process, is that it required elaborating on the concept that an architecture is a very complex property of a system rather than a thing itself.

##  Abstract:
IEEE Standard 1471 identifies sound practices to establish a framework and vocabulary for software architecture concepts.In 2000, the Computer Society approved IEEE Standard 1471, which documents a consensus on good architectural description practices. Five core concepts and relationships provide the foundation for the approved IEEE 1471 version: every system has an architecture, but an architecture is not a system; an architecture and an architecture description are not the same thing; architecture standards, descriptions, and development processes can differ and be developed separately; architecture descriptions are inherently multiviewed; and separating the concept of an object's view from its specification is an effective way to write architecture description standards. IEEE 1471 focuses on both software intensive systems and more general systems, such as information systems, embedded systems, systems-of-systems, product lines, and product families in which software plays a substantial role in development, operation, or evolution.
